title: Business Rules - Exposures and Reserves
subtitle: Automate claim processing by configuring business rules for activities, exposures, and reserves.

blocks.scenario: Imagine you're a claims manager, constantly assigning the same follow-up tasks, updating claim statuses, and creating records for routine events. This manual work is time-consuming and prone to errors, especially with a high volume of claims. How can you ensure consistency and efficiency across all claims without adding to your team's administrative burden?
blocks.question: What if you could automate these repetitive tasks, freeing your team to focus on complex claim resolution?

blocks.priorKnowledge: You're likely familiar with 'to-do' lists or task management systems in your daily work. ClaimCenter uses a similar concept called 'Activities' to track tasks related to claims. Think about how automating simple, repetitive tasks can streamline any workflow.
blocks.warmupQuestion: What are some routine tasks in claim handling that, if automated, could significantly improve efficiency?
blocks.hint: Consider tasks like initial contact, follow-ups, or status updates.

blocks.heading: Introduction to Business Activity Rules
blocks.narrative:
In ClaimCenter, **Activities** are essentially items in a 'to-do' list, guiding users on what needs to be accomplished and by when. They can have due dates and escalation indicators to ensure timely completion. While activities are crucial for tracking tasks, manually creating and assigning them for every claim can become an administrative burden. This is where **Business Activity Rules** come into play.

Business activity rules are a powerful feature in ClaimCenter designed to automatically create activities, history records, and even update field values based on specific conditions. This automation significantly reduces the administrative overhead for managers and ensures that line workers are always clear on their tasks and priorities. An administrator can create these rules with only limited knowledge of the ClaimCenter data model, making them accessible to business analysts who need to respond quickly to changing business needs without requiring custom coding.

These rules are managed directly within the ClaimCenter administration user interface, under **Administration > Business Settings > Business Rules > Activity Rules**. This centralized management allows for quick deployment without any server downtime, making ClaimCenter highly adaptable. The user interface also provides filtering capabilities, allowing you to focus on specific sets of rules based on criteria like Loss Type, Policy Type, or Jurisdiction. It's important to remember that if a rule applies to 'All Loss Types', it will be returned in searches for specific loss types, as it still applies to that specific case.

Business activity rules automate the creation of activities, history records, and field updates.

The Activity Rules UI allows for filtering, adding, cloning, exporting, and importing rules.

callouts.title: No-Code Automation
callouts.content: Leveraging business activity rules allows business analysts to implement changes without developer intervention, significantly speeding up response times to evolving business requirements.

callouts.title: Filtering 'All' Rules
callouts.content: When filtering rules by specific criteria (e.g., a particular Loss Type), rules configured to apply to 'All Loss Types' will also appear in the results, as they inherently apply to the specific type you're filtering for.

blocks.heading: Defining Business Activity Rules: Basics and Conditions
blocks.narrative:
Every business activity rule is meticulously defined with several core components to ensure it executes precisely when needed. First, each rule requires a **Name** and a **Description** for clear identification and understanding. Crucially, you must specify a **Trigger Entity**, which determines *which* ClaimCenter object will cause the rule to be evaluated. Common options include `claim`, `exposure`, `checkset`, and `recoveryset`. For instance, if the trigger entity is 'exposure', the rule will only activate when an action occurs on an exposure entity.

Following the trigger entity, the **Trigger Action** specifies *what type* of event on that entity will fire the rule. Options typically include `creation`, `update`, and `exception`. If a rule is set to 'creation' on an exposure, it will only run when a new exposure is created. However, if set to 'update', it will execute whenever an exposure is modified, which also encompasses its initial creation. You can also control the rule's active status with an 'Enabled' setting.

To further refine when a rule applies, you can use the **Applies To** section. Here, you can restrict the rule's application based on specific **Loss Types**, **Policy Types**, and **Claim Jurisdictions**. By selecting specific values instead of 'All', you narrow the scope of the rule. Be cautious, though: selecting mutually exclusive combinations (e.g., Loss Type = Travel and Policy Type = Workers' Compensation) will result in a rule that never fires. For complex conditions, **Rule Variables** can be defined to simplify reading and writing rule conditions, often based on data accessible from the trigger entity.

Finally, **Rule Conditions** provide the most granular control over rule execution. If set to 'None', the rule will execute for all candidates meeting the trigger and 'Applies To' requirements. Otherwise, you can specify one or more criteria that must be met. These criteria can be joined using **AND** (all must be true) or **OR** (at least one must be true) logic, or a combination of both. Conditions have direct access to data within the triggering entity, allowing you to use dot notation (e.g., `claim.LossType`) to reference specific attributes, with type-ahead assistance for ease of use.
keyPoints: Rules require a name, description, trigger entity (e.g., claim, exposure), and trigger action (creation, update, exception).
The 'Applies To' section allows restricting rules by Loss Type, Policy Type, and Claim Jurisdiction.
Mutually exclusive 'Applies To' selections will prevent a rule from ever firing.
Rule variables simplify complex conditions by pre-defining data points.
Rule Conditions use AND/OR logic to specify criteria, accessing trigger entity data via dot notation.

figures.caption: Rule definition basics include a name, description, and the trigger entity that initiates the rule.
The trigger action defines the event (creation, update, exception) on the entity that fires the rule.
The 'Applies To' section allows rules to be restricted by loss type, policy type, and claim jurisdiction.
Rule variables can be used to simplify complex rule conditions by referencing accessible data.

callouts.title: Mutually Exclusive Conditions
callouts.content: Be careful when setting 'Applies To' values. Selecting a Loss Type and Policy Type that cannot co-exist (e.g., Travel Loss Type with Workers' Compensation Policy Type) will create a rule that can never be triggered.

callouts.title: Using Type-Down for Fields
callouts.content: When defining rule conditions or setting field values, use the type-down (autocomplete) feature. This helps you quickly locate the correct fields and avoids typographical errors, ensuring your rules function as intended.

blocks.heading: Defining Business Activity Rules: Actions
blocks.narrative:
Once a candidate claim or exposure triggers a rule and satisfies all its defined conditions, the **Actions** section dictates 'what to do'. A single rule can execute one or more actions, and you can combine different action types as needed. ClaimCenter business activity rules support three primary action types: **Generate Activity**, **Generate History Event**, and **Set Field**.

When you choose to **Generate Activity**, you must specify an **Activity Pattern**. This pattern serves as a template, providing default attributes for the new activity. While the activity pattern defines the initial parameters, the rule creator can override these inherited values. This allows for customization of aspects like assignment logic (e.g., auto-assign), priority, subject, description, and target dates, ensuring the generated activity is tailored to the specific context of the rule.

The **Set Field** action type is incredibly useful for dynamically updating values on the triggering entity (e.g., a claim or exposure) based on the rule's conditions. For example, you might use this action to set a 'Special Investigation Escalation Date' to the current date when a specific escalation rule is executed. Similar to defining conditions, the user interface provides type-ahead assistance when selecting the field and defining its value, which can be a literal or a formula (e.g., `Util.currentDate()`). You also have the option to 'Set Only If Field Is Blank', preventing the rule from overwriting existing data.

Finally, the **Generate History Event** action allows you to create a timestamped record of significant actions or events within ClaimCenter. This is invaluable for auditing and understanding the lifecycle of a claim. When adding a history record, you must specify the **Type** of history event (e.g., 'Data change', 'Reserve created', 'Policy edited'), the entity it is **Related To** (which is typically 'Claim'), and a descriptive **Description** of the event. These history records provide a clear audit trail, documenting automated actions taken by the business rules.
keyPoints: Rules can execute one or more actions, including Generate Activity, Set Field, and Generate History Event.
Generating an activity requires an Activity Pattern, whose parameters can be overridden by the rule.
The Set Field action updates entity fields, allowing for dynamic values and 'set only if blank' options.
Generating a history event creates a timestamped record, requiring a type, related entity, and description.
History events are crucial for auditing and tracking automated actions within ClaimCenter.

figures.caption: Actions define what a rule does when triggered, including generating activities, setting fields, or creating history records.
The 'Add Activity' action requires an Activity Pattern, with customizable parameters like assignment and description.
The 'Set a Field Value' action allows rules to update specific fields on an entity, with options to prevent overwriting.
The 'Add a History Record' action creates timestamped event logs, requiring a type, related entity, and description.

callouts.title: Use Activity Patterns
callouts.content: Always start with an Activity Pattern when generating activities. This ensures consistency and provides a baseline for the activity's attributes, which can then be fine-tuned by the rule.

callouts.title: Formulas for Dynamic Values
callouts.content: When setting field values, leverage formula expressions like `Util.currentDate()` to dynamically populate fields with system-generated values, enhancing the rule's flexibility.

blocks.scenario: Your company has identified a new business requirement: for all new Commercial Auto claims, an activity must be automatically created to 'Review coverage in question' within 3 business days. This activity should be assigned to the claim owner.
blocks.question: How would you configure a new business activity rule in ClaimCenter to meet this requirement?
hints: What should be the Trigger Entity and Trigger Action for a *new* claim?
How would you specify that this rule only applies to Commercial Auto claims?
Which action type would you use to create a new task, and what parameters would you need to set for assignment and due date?
blocks.expectedApproach: Create a new activity rule. Set the Trigger Entity to 'Claim' and Trigger Action to 'Creation'. In 'Applies To', select 'Commercial Auto' for Policy Type. Add a 'Generate Activity' action, selecting an appropriate activity pattern, then override parameters to set the subject, description, and a target date formula for 3 business days, ensuring it's auto-assigned to the claim owner.

blocks.heading: Managing Business Activity Rule Lifecycle and Migration
blocks.narrative:
The effective management of business activity rules extends beyond their creation; it involves a structured lifecycle and migration process, typically moving from a development environment to production. It's a **best practice** to create and thoroughly test all business activity rules in a dedicated development environment. This allows for iterative testing and modification to ensure the rules produce the expected results without impacting live operations. While ClaimCenter does allow for 'on-the-fly' rule creation in a production environment for urgent situations (like catastrophe management), this should generally be avoided in favor of a controlled development-to-production pipeline.

The lifecycle of a business activity rule involves several statuses. On a **development server**, a newly created rule begins in **Draft** status, indicating it's still under construction or testing. Once the rule has been fully tested and approved, it is promoted to **Staged** status. This 'Staged' status signifies that the rule is ready for deployment to other environments. From the development server, only rules in 'Staged' status can be exported.

When a 'Staged' rule is imported into a **production server**, it initially retains the 'Staged' status. For the rule to become active and evaluated at runtime in production, its status must be changed to **Approved**. Once 'Approved', the rule is considered **Deployed** and will begin executing. This phased approach ensures that only validated and approved rules affect the live ClaimCenter system. The process of **exporting, downloading, and importing rules** is managed from the Activity Rules page in both development and production environments. After an export is complete (indicated by 100% progress), the rule file can be downloaded and then imported into the target server, maintaining the 'Staged' status upon import until it's manually 'Approved' for deployment.
keyPoints: Rules should be created and tested in a development environment before migrating to production.
The rule lifecycle includes Draft (development), Staged (ready for deployment), Approved (ready for production execution), and Deployed (executing in production) statuses.
Only 'Staged' rules can be exported from a development server.
Imported rules arrive as 'Staged' and must be 'Approved' to execute in production.
Rules are exported and imported via the Activity Rules page, with progress tracking.

figures.caption: Business activity rules should be developed and tested in a development environment before migration to production.
The rule lifecycle progresses through Draft, Staged, Approved, and Deployed statuses across environments.
Rules are exported and imported through the Activity Rules page, with status tracking for the process.

callouts.title: Development First
callouts.content: Always prioritize creating and testing business rules in a development environment. This minimizes risks and ensures stability in your production system.

callouts.title: Production Deployment
callouts.content: While possible, creating rules directly in production should be reserved for extreme, urgent situations. A controlled migration process is always preferred.

callouts.title: BizRulesDeploymentEnabled
callouts.content: For business rules to be deployed in production, the `BizRulesDeploymentEnabled` configuration parameter must be set to `true` in `config.xml`.

keyTakeaways: Business activity rules automate tasks, history records, and field updates in ClaimCenter.
Rules are defined by a name, description, trigger entity, trigger action, and enabled status.
Further restrictions can be applied using 'Applies To' criteria (Loss Type, Policy Type, Jurisdiction) and 'Rule Conditions' with AND/OR logic.
Actions include generating activities (based on patterns), setting field values (with formulas), and creating history events.
Rules follow a lifecycle (Draft, Staged, Approved, Deployed) and are migrated between environments via export/import.
blocks.realWorldConnection: In real Guidewire projects, mastering business activity rules is crucial for building efficient and adaptable claims systems. By automating routine processes, you empower claims adjusters to focus on complex decision-making, improve data consistency, and ensure compliance with business policies. This directly translates to faster claim resolution, reduced operational costs, and enhanced customer satisfaction.
